com.vaadin.polymer.paper

Interface PaperRippleElement

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Element, EventTarget, HTMLElement, Node

    @JsType(isNative=true)
public interface PaperRippleElement
extends HTMLElement

    Material design: Surface reaction

    paper-ripple provides a visual effect that other paper elements can
    use to simulate a rippling effect emanating from the point of contact. The
    effect can be visualized as a concentric circle with motion.

    Example:

    <div style="position:relative">
   <paper-ripple></paper-ripple>
 </div>

    Note, it’s important that the parent container of the ripple be relative position, otherwise
    the ripple will emanate outside of the desired container.

    paper-ripple listens to “mousedown” and “mouseup” events so it would display ripple
    effect when touches on it. You can also defeat the default behavior and
    manually route the down and up actions to the ripple element. Note that it is
    important if you call downAction() you will have to make sure to call
    upAction() so that paper-ripple would end the animation loop.

    Example:

    <paper-ripple id="ripple" style="pointer-events: none;"></paper-ripple>
 ...
 downAction: function(e) {
   this.$.ripple.downAction({detail: {x: e.x, y: e.y}});
 },
 upAction: function(e) {
   this.$.ripple.upAction();
 }

    Styling ripple effect:

    Use CSS color property to style the ripple:

    paper-ripple {
   color: #4285f4;
 }

    Note that CSS color property is inherited so it is not required to set it on
    the paper-ripple element directly.

    By default, the ripple is centered on the point of contact. Apply the recenters
    attribute to have the ripple grow toward the center of its container.

    <paper-ripple recenters></paper-ripple>

    You can also center the ripple inside its container from the start.

    <paper-ripple center></paper-ripple>

    Apply circle class to make the rippling effect within a circle.

    <paper-ripple class="circle"></paper-ripple>

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addOwnKeyBinding(Object eventString, Object handlerName)
      Can be used to imperatively add a key binding to the implementing
      element.
      void addRipple()
      JavaScript Info:
      void animate()
      This conflicts with Element#antimate().
      https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/animate
      void downAction(com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject event)
      Provokes a ripple down effect via a UI event,
      not respecting the noink property.
      boolean getAnimating()
      True when there are visible ripples animating within the
      element.
      boolean getCenter()
      If true, ripples will center inside its container
      boolean getHoldDown()
      If true, the ripple will remain in the “down” state until holdDown
      is set to false again.
      double getInitialOpacity()
      The initial opacity set on the wave.
      com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject getKeyBindings()
      JavaScript Info:
      com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject getKeyEventTarget()
      The EventTarget that will be firing relevant KeyboardEvents.
      boolean getNoink()
      If true, the ripple will not generate a ripple effect
      via pointer interaction.
      Calling ripple’s imperative api like simulatedRipple will
      still generate the ripple effect.
      double getOpacityDecayVelocity()
      How fast (opacity per second) the wave fades out.
      boolean getRecenters()
      If true, ripples will exhibit a gravitational pull towards
      the center of their container as they fade away.
      com.google.gwt.core.client.JsArray getRipples()
      A list of the visual ripples.
      boolean getStopKeyboardEventPropagation()
      If true, this property will cause the implementing element to
      automatically stop propagation on any handled KeyboardEvents.
      boolean keyboardEventMatchesKeys(com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject event, String eventString)
      Returns true if a keyboard event matches eventString.
      void onAnimationComplete()
      JavaScript Info:
      void removeOwnKeyBindings()
      When called, will remove all imperatively-added key bindings.

      void uiDownAction(com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject event)
      Provokes a ripple down effect via a UI event,
      respecting the noink property.
      void uiUpAction(com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject event)
      Provokes a ripple up effect via a UI event,
      respecting the noink property.
      void upAction(com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject event)
      Provokes a ripple up effect via a UI event,
      not respecting the noink property.
